For example, gradually detaching from the love of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, a faith-liberated one transforms their faculties to become a view-attainer, abandoning the antidote that cuts off the path of cultivation in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. Is it to abandon that abandonment?
If it is abandoned, why is the bond not accomplished?
If it is not abandoned, the antidote is already abandoned. For what reason is the abandonment not abandoned?
Answer:
Some say there is no gradual detachment from the love of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception while transforming faculties.
If there is a transformation, it is either a regression or a final detachment.

There is also an explanation that there are those who gradually detach from the craving for the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and change faculties, abandoning the counteractive path but not abandoning the severance.
The judges say:
It should be said:
Abandoning the counteractive path also means abandoning the severance, but one does not accomplish the bonds.

Just as when detaching from the craving for the sphere of nothingness, one ends one's life and is reborn in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, all the counteractive paths and severances from the desire realm up to the sphere of consciousness are abandoned, but one does not accomplish the bonds.
It is the same for that.
When a faith-liberated one changes faculties to become a view-attainer, they use one expedient path, one unobstructed path, and one liberation path.
When a time-liberated one changes faculties to become immovable, some say they use one expedient path, one unobstructed path, and one liberation path.
The judges say:
It should be said:
They use one expedient path, nine unobstructed paths, and nine liberation paths.
Why is it so?
Because one must again exert effort to attain the fruit of a higher stage of spiritual development.
Just as a person who destroys a house and then rebuilds it is said to exert effort again,
so is it in this case.

When a faith-liberated person transforms their faculties to become a view-attainer, the path of preparation is both contaminated and uncontaminated, and they cultivate both contaminated and uncontaminated paths in the future;
the unobstructed path is uncontaminated, and they also cultivate the uncontaminated path in the future;
the path of liberation is also uncontaminated.
Some say that in the future they cultivate both contaminated and uncontaminated paths.
Some say that they only cultivate the uncontaminated path.

When a time-liberated person transforms their faculties to become immovable, the path of preparation is both contaminated and uncontaminated, and they cultivate both contaminated and uncontaminated paths in the future;
the nine unobstructed paths and eight paths of liberation are only uncontaminated, and they cultivate the uncontaminated path in the future;
the final path of liberation is uncontaminated, and they cultivate both contaminated and uncontaminated paths in the future, as well as the wholesome roots of the three realms.

When a faith-liberated one transforms faculties to become a view-attained one, the path of preparation may be either previously attained or not, the path of non-obstruction and the path of liberation are definitely not previously attained.

When a time-liberated one transforms faculties to become immovable, the path of preparation may be either previously attained or not, the path of non-obstruction and the path of liberation are definitely not previously attained.

When a faith-liberated one transforms faculties to become a view-attained one, the path of preparation and the path of non-obstruction are categorized as the path of a faith-liberated one, the path of liberation is categorized as the path of a view-attained one.

When a time-liberated one transforms faculties to become immovable, the path of preparation and the nine paths of non-obstruction and eight paths of liberation are categorized as the path of a time-liberated one, the final path of liberation is categorized as the path of a non-time-liberated one.

When a faith-liberated one transforms faculties to become a view-attained one, if one transforms faculties while abiding in the path of fruition, the path of preparation, the path of non-obstruction, and the path of liberation are categorized as the path of fruition.

If one abides in the superior fruit path and changes faculties, then the expedient and unobstructed paths are included in the superior fruit path, and the path of liberation is included in the fruit path.
When a temporarily liberated one changes faculties to become unshakable, the expedient, unobstructed, and liberated paths are included in the fruit path.
Why is this?
Because there is no superior fruit path.
When a faith-liberated one changes faculties to become a view-attainer, if one changes faculties while abiding in the fruit, it is called abandoning the fruit and attaining the fruit.
If one changes faculties while abiding in the superior fruit path, it is called abandoning the fruit and abandoning the superior fruit path to attain the fruit.
When a temporarily liberated one changes faculties to become unshakable, it is called abandoning the fruit and attaining the fruit.
There are six kinds of arhats: those who regress, those who die having attained, those who guard, those who abide equally, those who can progress, and those who are unshakable.

If one who is liable to regress changes faculties to become one who dies having attained, one abandons the faculties of one liable to regress and attains the faculties of one who dies having attained.
If one who recollects the Dharma changes faculties and becomes one who protects the Dharma, one abandons the faculty of recollecting the Dharma and obtains the faculty of protecting the Dharma.
If one who protects the Dharma changes faculties and becomes one who abides equally, one abandons the faculty of protecting the Dharma and obtains the faculty of abiding equally.
If one who abides equally changes faculties and becomes one who can progress, one abandons the faculty of abiding equally and obtains the faculty of being able to progress.
If one who can progress changes faculties and becomes unshakable, one abandons the faculty of being able to progress and obtains the unshakable faculty.
Just as there are six kinds in the stage of no-more-learning, so it is also in the stage of learning with six kinds.
Question:

When one of weak faculties changes faculties and becomes unshakable, does one abide in the faculty of weak faculties and obtain unshakable faculties, or does one gradually change through the five faculties and obtain unshakable faculties?
Answer:
Some say: One abides in the faculty of weak faculties and changes faculties to obtain unshakable faculties.
The stage of no-more-learning is different, and it is difficult to attain through much effort, so it is gradually changed;
the stage of learning is not like this.
The discussion says:
It should be said:
They all turn in sequence at all times.
Just as there are six types of natures in the path of cultivation, there are also six types of natures in the path of seeing, namely the nature of falling away up to the immovable.
There is no one who changes faculties.
Why is it so?
Because the path of seeing is swift and does not give rise to the path.
Just as there are six types of natures in the path of seeing, there are also six types of natures in the stage of cultivation, namely the nature of falling away up to the immovable.

If one changes, the nature of falling away and the nature of heat do not appear before one, but the nature of recollection and the nature of heat appear before one. Up to the nature of progress and the nature of heat do not appear before one, but the immovable nature of heat appears before one. The nature of heat of the Å›rÄvaka does not appear before one, but the nature of heat of the pratyekabuddha appears before one. The nature of heat of the pratyekabuddha does not appear before one, but the nature of heat of the Buddha appears before one.
Just as with the nature of heat, the nature of the summit is also like this.
As for the distinctions in patience, the patience of the Å›rÄvaka nature is not present, while the patience of the pratyekabuddha nature is present.
There is no patience of the Å›rÄvaka and pratyekabuddha that is not present, but the patience of the Buddha is present.
Why is this?
Patience obstructs the evil destinies.
Because the bodhisattva, by the power of his vows, will be born in the evil destinies.
Furthermore, there are those who say that the heat and peak of the Å›rÄvaka are not present and do not arise, while the heat and peak of the pratyekabuddha are present.
Why is this?
Just as the Buddha is self-enlightened and has no teacher,
so is the pratyekabuddha.
Just as the Buddha, sitting in one cross-legged posture, gives rise to the wholesome dharmas that are present, from impurity up to the knowledge of extinction and non-production,
so is the pratyekabuddha.
The supreme worldly dharmas also have six natures, from the dharma of regression up to the immovable, without changing faculties.
Why is this?
Because those wholesome roots are momentary and have no characteristic of abiding.
There are six types of stream-enterers, from those who regress to those who are unshakable. Therefore, it is said like this.
Can one regress from the fruit of stream-entry without losing the bonds severed by the path of seeing?
Answer:
There can be.
